Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Green Processes, East China Normal University No. 500 Dongchuan Road Shanghai 200241 China The production of amine intermediates from biomass is capturing increasing attention. Herein, an efficient conversion of furfural to furfural amine over RuCo/AC catalyst under hydrothermal conditions has been investigated. The effects of different carriers, bimetals, and reaction conditions were systematically investigated in green solvents (water). Fully conversion of furfural and high furfural amine yield (92.13%) at 80 ℃ for 1 h over 4Ru1Co/AC. The excellent catalytic performance of 4Ru1Co/AC was attributed to its high acidity and good hydrogenation ability, as well as the synergistic effect between Ru-Co alloy formations and the activated carbon. Importantly, the highly selective preparation of furfural to furfural amine is a promising way to high-value utilization of cellulosic biomass in green solvents. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Furfural amine Catalytic amination Activated carbon Bimetal Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Biomass is widely distributed and readily available in nature and is an important feedstock for future renewable fuel, chemical, and energy production. The conversion of biomass into fuels or high-value-added chemicals is one of the ways to address the depletion of fossil resources and the growing environmental problems. [1–3] Amines are important chemicals in the industry, widely used in the dye industry, flavors, polymers, and pharmaceutical production, [4–6] but its large-scale production is still obtained from fossil resources through industrial processes and the toxic and harmful raw materials used in the production process cause more and more energy and environmental problems. Finding a sustainable approach to amines with renewable resources has been a hot topic for researchers in recent years. The use of biomass and its platform compounds is considered an environmentally friendly option for obtaining amine-based chemicals. [7–10] As an important platform compound downstream of cellulose, furfural is listed by the U.S. Department of Energy as one of the platform compounds with good development prospects. Furfural amine has attracted much attention for its many applications in the manufacture of pharmaceuticals, pesticides, antihypertensives, etc. Therefore, the use of furfural as a raw material for the production of furfural amines has indisputable practical significance in terms of both energy crisis and environmental protection [11–13]. Recently, many researchers have obtained furfural amines by catalyzing the reduction amination of furfural. In the process of aldehyde and ketamine, Ru-based catalysts are widely used because of their high activity. [14–17] Chen [18] used Ru catalysts supported on boron/nitrogen co-doped carbon efficiently achieves a yield of 99% of furfural amines with hydrous hydrazine as a nitrogen source and hydrazone as an intermediate. Komanoya [19] used Ru/Nb2O5, using methanol as the solvent, ammonia water as the nitrogen source, and flushed into 4 MPa hydrogen as a reducing agent, and achieved an 89% yield of furfural amine at a low temperature (90 ℃) for 4 h. After using ammonia gas instead of methanol solution, a yield of 99% furfural amine was obtained. Chandra [20] and Gould [21] also demonstrated the excellent performance of Ru-based catalysts in catalytic reductive amination in their study. Other noble and non-noble metals have also been reported. [22–26] Chatterjee [27] used Rh/Al2O3, ammonia water as a nitrogen source, hydrogen as a reducing agent, and achieved a conversion efficiency of 91.5% from furfural to furfural amine after a two-hour reaction in water and under mild conditions (80 ℃). Zhou [28] used Rani cobalt, methanol and n-dodecane as solvents, charged ammonia and hydrogen, and obtained a yield of 98.8% furfural at 120 ℃ for two hours. In the reported literature, there are problems such as low catalyst economy, cumbersome and complex production and structure, and the reaction system is mostly organic solvents, which do not meet the requirements of green chemistry. The reductive amination reaction of aldehyde or ketone can be divided into several successive steps. Condensation of carbonyl compounds and amines forms a methanolamine, which removes water to produce imine or Schiff bases, and subsequently, the imine intermediate is reduced to an amine. Because primary amines are better nucleophiles than ammonia, and it is easy to form lower value secondary or tertiary amines. [21,29] The nature of the metal component is probably the parameter that having a major influence on the selectivity of the primary amines, metals with high hydrogenation activity promote the formation of secondary amines and alcohols, and metals with weak or moderate hydrogenation activity promote the formation of primary amines. [30] Through the design and optimize of catalysts to solve the competitive relationship between primary amines and carbonyl nucleophilic reactions and their hydrogenation reactions. The use of bimetallic catalysts is a promising option for biomass feedstock upgrading, as the interaction between metals can modify the surface properties of the catalyst. These changes can significantly improve catalytic activity, alter the selectivity of the desired product, and improve the stability of the catalyst in the presence of biomass reaction conditions. [31]. In this study, the selectivity of Ru-based catalysts in furfural catalyzed reductive amination in green solvent (water) was investigated. The optimized 4Ru1Co/AC showed good catalytic performance and high selectivity of target products through optimization study. For realizing the amination of the upstream monosaccharide compound of furfural, and thereby realizing the one-pot conversion process of monosaccharide to furfural amine, it has important reference significance in industrial application. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials ZrO2, CeO2 and SiO2 was purchased from Aladdin Chemical. C and RuCl3 was purchased from Adamas-beta. Ammonia solution was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical ReagentCo., Ltd. Furfural (Adamas-beta), furfural amine (Adamas-beta), furfuryl alcohol (Adamas-beta) were purchased and used as received. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Ru-supported catalysts were prepared by precipitation. Typically, the carrier was dissolved in water and stirred for one hour, and then the configured aqueous solution of ruthenium trichloride (the corresponding metal salt solution was added in bimetallic catalysts) was added and stirred for one hour. Then adjusted the solution pH to 10 stirring for two hours. The solution was filtered and washed with distilled water to neutral, dried overnight at 90 ℃, then placed in a muffle furnace at 500 ℃ for 5 h, and the unreduced catalyst was obtained after grinding (the activated carbon support catalyst does not have the stage of muffle oven roasting). Finally, the prepared catalysts were reduced at 400 ℃ for 2 h in a continuous flow of H2 and N2 mixture before using. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Scanning electron microscopy (SEM; Zeiss GeminiSEM450) and Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM; FEI Tecnai G2 F30) was used to examine the morphological characteristics and crystal of the catalysts. Nitrogen adsorption isotherms were measured at − 196 ℃ using an Autosorb-IQ apparatus (Micromeritics). All samples were degassed for 6 h at 200 ℃ in a nitrogen flow prior to the physisorption measurements. H2-TPR were carried out using a multifunctional dynamic adsorption instrument equipped with a TCD detector (Micromeritics AutoChem Discovery). 0.1 g of the catalyst was loaded in a quartz tube reactor, and heated in N2 flow at 350 ℃ for 1 h with a ramp of 10 ℃/min. The sample was cooled down to 50 ℃ and switched to 5% H2/N2 mixture for reduction. After the baseline was stabilized, the temperature was raised to 800 ℃ at a ramp of 10 ℃/min and the consumption of hydrogen was recorded by TCD. CuO powder was used to calibrate the detector signal. BD-IR was measured using NicoS 670 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer produced by Nicolet. The specific test method is as follows: Take 30 mg of sample pressing into pieces, place the sample in a vacuum infrared tank and vacuum under 723 K, 1 h under the vacuum, and after the temperature of the infinite pool is reduced to room temperature, the pyridine valve is opened and adsorbed for 30 min to Saturated, then adsorbed pyridine was removed from the catalyst surface at different temperatures (323–723 K) and was subjected to infrared spectroscopy test. XRD patterns were obtained using a Rigaku SmartlabSE X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kαradiation. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) was performed on a Shimadzu Axis Supra X-ray photoelectron spectrometer with Al Kαradiation for the X-ray source. The binding energies of Ru 3p were calibrated by referencing to the C1s line at 284.6 eV. 2.4 General procedure for reductive amination of furfural The experiments of the catalysts for reductive amination of furfural were carried out in a 50 ml autoclave with a temperature and pressure display. In all reactions, the solvents were ammonia water and distilled water. Generally, furfural (100 mg), catalyst (50 mg) and ammonia solution (5 ml) were added to the autoclave. The autoclave was closed, flushed with H2 five times to remove air, and then pure H2 gas was charged until the pressure of 2 MPa. After the reaction, the autoclave was cooled down in ice water and then depressurized slowly. The liquid of the autoclave was extracted using dichloromethane, and the liquid products were identified by GC-MS. The conversion rate and yield of the product were determined by the internal standard method, which internal standard substance was 1,4 epoxy hexacyclic. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance on reductive amination of furfural The effects of catalysts on the reductive amination of furfural with ammonia solution and H2 were studied, and the results were shown in Table 1. To improve the yield of furfural amine, different commercial catalyst carriers (ZrO2, CeO2, SiO2, AC) were selected, and the noble metal ruthenium supported on the support for the reaction. During the response, furfural is converted to furfural amines (2a) and some by-products such as furfural alcohol (2b), tetrahydrofurfurylamine (2c), difurfurylamine (2d), and the like. From the results, the metal ruthenium loading on ZrO2, CeO2, and SiO2 has a specific effect on the conversion of furfural to furfural amine. Still, the yield of furfural amine is not high, which is related to the weak acidity of the catalyst surface and the weaker hydrogenation capacity. Compared with ZrO2, CeO2, SiO2, Ru/AC shows good primary amine conversion, which may be due to the high metal dispersed caused by the large specific surface area of activated carbon. And there are literature reports that treated activated carbon will produce different types and concentrations of acidic sites. [32,33] After the introduction of the assist metal (RuFe, RuCo, RuNi, RuRh), the furfural amine selectivity has been improved, of which RuCo selectivity has increased by up to 59% (Entry 8), which is related to its high acidity and good hydrogenation properties, and also related to the interaction between ruthenium and cobalt bimetals. For bimetallic RuPt (Entry 12), it has a low catalytic effect on furfural amination conversion, this indicates that direct hydrogenation of carbonyl groups on metal Pt is not the main pathway and that the activity of metal Pt is inhibited by the generated amines. [29] After optimizing the ratio of substrate to bimetal, the amount of catalyst added, the temperature and time of the reaction, the yield of furfural amine on the catalyst 4Ru1Co/AC reached 92% (Entry 9). However, the Ru/AC and Co/AC catalysts were added 25 mg each, and under the optimized conditions, the yield of furfural amine obtained was only 16% (Entry 13), which confirmed that there was a synergistic effect between Ru and Co in the 4Ru1Co/AC catalyst. 3.2 Catalytic characterization of different catalysts The textural properties of 2 wt% Ru metal catalysts supported on different carriers were shown in Table 2. The specific surface area of these catalysts ranged from 36 to 1263 m2/g, and activated carbon showed a higher specific surface area and a larger microporous volume. This is also confirmed by the isothermal adsorption curve of activated carbon (Fig. S1), which increased significantly during the low-pressure adsorption stage, indicating that the pore of AC is microporous mainly, and this can also be observed in the pore size distribution (Fig. S2). The textural properties of the bimetallic load on carbon were shown in Tab. S1. When the content of the metal is 5 wt%, the specific surface area, microporous volume, mesoporous volume and pore size of activated carbon do not change significantly. It shows that the metal is evenly distributed on the surface of activated carbon and well dispersed, and no clusters occur. Fig. 1 showed the XRD spectra of Ru supported on four carriers (2 wt% Ru), due to the content of ruthenium being low, except for Ru/SiO2, which has a smaller metal ruthenium diffraction peak. No other ruthenium catalysts have a diffraction peak of ruthenium, indicating that ruthenium is highly dispersed on the carrier and the particle size is less than 4 nm, which can be confirmed in Fig. S3 by TEM. [34,35] On activated carbon, the XRD spectra of different ruthenium loading were shown in Fig. 2. When the metal loading is 0.5 wt% and 2 wt%, the diffraction peak of the ruthenium does not appear. While the metal loading amount is 5 wt%, 7 wt%, and 10 wt%, new diffraction peaks of Ru metal appear at 38.4° (100) and 44.0° (101), indicating that when the metal loading is over 5 wt%, the part of RuO2 species has been converted to metallic Ru during the reduction and reaction. When the loading amount was increased from 5 wt% to 10 wt%, the yield of furfural amine decreased from 44% to 26%, indicating that when the loading amount was more significant than 5 wt%, the catalytic activity of the catalyst showed a downward trend due to metal clusters and other reasons. As shown in Fig. 3, ruthenium catalysts of different carriers were characterized by pyridine adsorption infrared spectroscopy. The bands at 1606 and 1450 cm-1 are Lewis acid site (L acid), 1550 and 1490 cm−1 are Bronsted acid site (B acid) and B acid + L acid, respectively for all catalysts. The band at 1546 cm−1 represents the binding of pyridine to the Bronsted acid site caused by the vibration of the pyridine ion ring, and the band at 1610 cm−1 belongs to the strong Lewis acid are found in Ru/SiO2. There are the band at 1445 cm−1 represents hydrogen bond pyridine, the band at 1455 cm−1 represents strong L acid, and the band at 1583 cm−1 represents physically adsorbed pyridine in Ru/AC because the physically adsorbed pyridine of the sample at the current temperature cannot be removed from the surface, which is the cause of the wide peak. [36–38] Ru/CeO2 and Ru/ZrO2 do not exhibit significant acidity, which may be attributed to the nature of the carrier and the lower metal loading. The acidic action of the catalyst makes the electrophilic properties of the carbonyl group enhanced. After a nucleophilic attack, proton transfer and 1,2 elimination of H2O form primary imines, which migrate to metal functions and are hydrogenated. Fig. 4 showed the H2-TPR profile of ruthenium catalysts of different carriers (2 wt%). There is one reduction peak for Ru/CeO2, Ru/SiO2, and Ru/AC, while two reduction peaks for Ru/ZrO2. The lower reduction peak at about 130 ℃ is ascribed to the reduction of surface RuO2, and the higher reduction peak at about 150 ℃ is attributed to the reduction of interface RuO2. The broad peak of Ru/AC above 250 ℃ could be attributed to the methanation of carbon support catalyzed by ruthenium under hydrogen atmosphere. [39] Ru/AC reduction peak at about 80 ℃ is lower than the temperature of the ruthenium catalyst reduction peak of other carriers, indicating that the larger specific surface area of activated carbon makes the ruthenium metal particles formed smaller and easier to reduce, and the hydrogenation performance is better than that of other ruthenium support catalysts, which is more conducive to the conversion of furfural to furfural amine. The XRD patterns of bimetallic catalysts were displayed in Fig. 5. The XRD patterns of 4Ru1Fe/AC, 4Ru1Co/AC, and 4Ru1Ni/AC, compared with 4Ru1Rh/AC and 4Ru1Pt/AC, there no obvious characteristic peak of Ru in the spectrum, proving that after the introduction of Fe, Co, Ni, the dispersion of the metal is better than the introduction of Rh and Pt. H2-TPR was shown in Fig. 6 after the introduction of five other metals. At the reduction peak of about 100 ℃, 4Ru1Co/AC and 4Ru1Ni/AC are offset to low temperature compared with 4Ru1Fe/AC, indicating that the interaction force between RuCo and RuNi metal is stronger than RuFe, so that the reduction temperature is offset to the low-temperature, and the hydrogenation performance is improved. As shown in Fig. 7, the content of 4Ru1Co/AC in B acid and L acid is significantly increased than that of 4Ru1Ni/AC, which is in line with the performance of 4Ru1Co/AC in the experimental results, which further confirms the 4Ru1Co/AC catalyst High selectivity in the conversion of furfural to furfural amine. The elemental chemical state of the catalysts was investigated by XPS. The high-resolution Ru 3p spectra for the 4Ru1Co/AC and 5Ru/AC catalysts are given in Fig. 8. The deconvolution results, including the binding energy and relative content of different peaks, are shown in Tab. S2. For 5Ru/AC, about 85.1% of ruthenium was ascribed to the Ru0 species (462.2 eV) and about 14.9% of ruthenium was ascribed to the Ruσ+ species in RuOx (465.0 eV). The Ruσ+ species increased from 14.9% to 45.9% after introducing the metal Co, suggesting the formation of RuCo alloys in 4Ru1Co/AC. Metallic Ru can act as a catalyst to reduce Co from the high-valence state to the low-valence state in the RuCo alloy (Fig. S4, Tab. S3). [35,40] During the reduction process, the increase of Ruσ+ species allows charge transfer and the increase of Co0/Co2+ ratio to form more surface oxygen vacancies to promote catalytic reactions. And more Ruσ+ species exist, enhanced acidic sites favor carbonyl activation, and active metallic species favored the intermediate imine (Schiff base) hydrogenation. [30]. The microstructure of the 4Ru1Co/AC catalyst was further analyzed. Fig. 9 showed the SEM micrograph and EDS mapping of the 4Ru1Co/AC catalyst. The results show that the 4Ru1Co/AC catalyst has a normal activated carbon morphology, and Ru and Co are well distributed on the surface of activated carbon. TEM image of the 4Ru1Co/AC catalyst was shown in Fig. 10, the lattice fringes of 0.23 nm and 0.21 nm are assigned to the (100) and (002) lattice planes of the hexagonal RuCo alloy phase, respectively (Fig. 10b). [40] EDS line scan analysis showed that the distribution of metal Ru and metal Co on the surface of the carrier was consistent, further demonstrating the formation of the alloy structure (Fig. 10c). The crystal planes of 0.21 nm and 0.20 nm are attributed to the (101) and (111) planes of Ru and Co on the Ru/AC and Co/AC catalysts, respectively (Fig. S5). 3.3 Optimization of the reaction conditions 4Ru1Co/AC catalyst was proved as an effective catalyst for producing selectively furfural amine in the reductive amination of furfural. Subsequently, the effect of reaction conditions including Ru/Co ratio, reaction temperature, water/ammonia solution ratio, catalyst amount, and reaction time were further investigated over 4Ru1Co/AC. The yield of furfural to furfural amine when the ratio of Ru: Co at 4:1 (compared with 1:4, 2.5:2.5, 0:5) was the highest, which was consistent with the previous results obtained when bimetals were doped. Fig. 11a showed the effect of the reaction temperature on the reducing amination performance of furfural in the temperature range of 60–140 ℃. At a low temperature of 60 ℃, the yield of furfural amine is very low. When the temperature is slightly increased to 80 ℃, the yield of furfural amine is significantly improved and reaches a maximum of 67.71%. when the temperature increases to 100 ℃, the yield of furfural amine is reduced. Further increase in the temperature above 100 ℃ leads to a significant decrease in the yield of furfural amine, which may be attributed to the formation of unidentified products. [41] Therefore, 80 ℃ was selected as the ideal temperature to achieve the high selectivity of the target product. The high yield of primary amines also depends deeply on the concentration of ammonia solution, and Fig. 11b showed the yield of primary amines in different ratios of water/ammonia solution at 80 ℃. The yield of furfural amine may be changed by adjusting the water/ammonia solution ratio because adding ammonia could change the reductive amination of the -CHO group. When the ratio of water/ammonia solution is 4:1, the lowest yield of furfural amine has been obtained, and when the ratio is 1:4, the yield of furfural amine reaches the highest (89.7%), the further increased ammonia concentration is not conducive to the formation of furfural amine. The effect of the catalyst amount on the performance of reductive amination of furfural was shown in Fig. 11c. The yield of furfural amine increases gradually with the amount of 4Ru1Co/AC catalyst increases from 5 to 50 mg and reaches a maximum of 89.9% at 50 mg catalyst dosage. However, further increase in catalyst loading amount leads to a decrease in furfural amine yield, which indicated that an appropriate amount of catalyst can promote the conversion of furfural to furfural amine. The effect of reaction time on furfural amine yield was also examined. As shown in Fig. 11d, during reaction for 0.5 h, the yield of furfural amine was the lowest, and when the reaction time reached 1 h, the yield of furfural amine was the highest (92.13%). When the reaction time extended to 2–6 h, the yield of furfural amine decreased compared with 1 h but did not change significantly, possibly since furfural amine was relatively stable at about 80 ℃. 3.4 Probable reaction pathways The distribution of furfural reductive amination products by varying different reaction times using 4Ru1Co/AC was shown in Fig. S6 to explain the reaction pathway of the formation of furfural amine. When the reaction was more than 0.5 h, furfural was fully converted. The highest yield of 2a was quickly achieved at the reaction time of 1 h. When the reaction time was more than 1 h, the yield of 2a showed a decreasing trend while that of 2c was detected in 4 h, indicating that the hydrogenation of the furan ring takes place with time on stream. 2d was obtained by hydrogenation or hydrogenolysis of imine intermediates, and the yield of 2d did not change significantly with time on stream. Based on the above results, the possible reaction pathways are shown in Figs. 12, 1a and NH3 react to generate imines, due to the poor stability of the imines, the presence of imines was not detected in the product. The imine is reduced to 2a on the metallic function of the catalyst in the H2 atmosphere, and the over-hydrogenation of the furan ring on 2a generates 2c. Since 2a is more nucleophilic than NH3, 2a will preferentially form Schiff bases with 1a and further reduce to 2d by hydrogenation or hydrogenolysis. On the other hand, 1a can also be directly hydrogenated to form 2b, but this is not the main reaction of furfural reductive amination over 4Ru1Co/AC catalyst. [21,27,29,41]. 3.5 Catalyst reusability The reusability of 4Ru1Co/AC was investigated through five-time consecutive recycling under the optimized condition. After the reaction, the catalyst was separated from the product mixture by filtration, thoroughly washed with CH3OH, and dried for reuse. 4Ru1Co/AC maintained its catalytic activity during the synthesis of furfural amines without significant inactivation after five cycles ( Fig. 13), as confirmed by TEM images and XRD images before and after the reaction (Fig. S3, Fig. S7). 4 Conclusions In summary, we performed the reductive amination of furfural over Ru-based catalysts and activated carbon catalysts with different bimetallic. Compared with other Ru-based catalysts, Ru/AC has a higher yield on furfural amine. After the introduction of the second metal, the synergistic effect between ruthenium and cobalt enhanced the reductive amination of furfural compared to ruthenium and other metals such as iron, nickel, rhodium, and platinum. Besides, the acidity and hydrogenation properties of the 4Ru1Co/AC catalyst were also improved significantly. There was the alloy formed by Ru and Co, which can be stable existed on the surface of AC. Metallic Ru can act as a catalyst to reduce Co from the high-valence state to the low-valence state in the RuCo alloy, which makes the surface Co0 species increased and more surface oxygen vacancies formed. The 4Ru1Co/AC catalyst displayed the best catalytic performance for producing furfural amine. Under the optimized reaction conditions, the highest yield of 92.13% to furfural amine was achieved after the reaction 1 h at 80 ℃. These findings indicate that 4Ru1Co/AC is a potentially attractive catalyst in the conversion process of furfural to furfural amine, providing a potential road for further industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: The production of amine intermediates from biomass is capturing increasing attention. Herein, an efficient conversion of furfural to furfural amine over RuCo/AC catalyst under hydrothermal conditions has been investigated. The effects of different carriers, bimetals, and reaction conditions were systematically investigated in green solvents (water). Fully conversion of furfural and high furfural amine yield (92.13%) at 80 ℃ for 1 h over 4Ru1Co/AC. The excellent catalytic performance of 4Ru1Co/AC was attributed to its high acidity and good hydrogenation ability, as well as the synergistic effect between Ru-Co alloy formations and the activated carbon. Importantly, the highly selective preparation of furfural to furfural amine is a promising way to high-value utilization of cellulosic biomass in green solvents.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient conversion of furfural to furfural amine over 4Ru1Co/AC catalyst
